columns.text:
$a)$ Because of the interest deduction from taxes, it is important to adjust the firm's taxes first in order to value it, in general, each company has some debt in its capital that it pays interest on, any interest paid is tax-deductible, and the net profit was applied consistently.

 However, when a company is evaluated, it is necessary to ignore this influence in order to determine the true value of the company, such a tax break reduces a company's overall tax bill, if the corporation had no debt, the effect of such interest deductions would have been nullified, and the cash flows would be determined.

 As a consequence, when valuing a company, the tax expense must be adjusted.

$b)$ Since the terminal value of a corporation comprises both the value of equity and the value of debt, a ratio is employed to assess the firm's value, this amount of debt must be subtracted from the value of equity to determine the value of each share. 

This total value of equity is divided by the number of shares outstanding to get at the terminal value, even though it is simple to interpret what each dollar of an investment's assets is valued in the company, this valuation is conducted per share or each bond issued.

textbook.authors: Bradford D. Jordan, Randolph W. Westerfield, Stephen A. Ross
textbook.title: Fundamentals of Corporate Finance
